title: [Works]
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: My mind was thus highly prejudiced against the family I was about to serve ; so that I was half surprised, when I beheld Durrisdeer itself, lying in a pretty, sheltered bay, under the Abbey Hill ; the house most commodiously built in the French fashion or perhaps Italianate, for I have

title: Traditions of Edinburgh.
author: Chambers, Robert
snippet: I should suppose the house to have been that respectable old villa, at the extremity of the suburb of Abbey Hill, in which the late Baron Norton, of the Court of Exchequer, lived for many years.

title: Traditions of Edinburgh.
author: Chambers, Robert
snippet: Her Grace lived in a house at the Abbey Hill, where, as we are informed by Wodrow in a tone of pious horror,* she openly kept a kind of college for instructing young people in Jesuitism and Jacobitism together.

title: Traditions of Edinburgh.
author: Chambers, Robert
snippet: Nay, so late as 1832, I had the pleasure of breakfasting with Sir William Macleod Bannatyne in Whiteford House, Canongate  (now a type-foundry), on which occasion the venerable  old gentleman talked as familiarly of the levees of the sous-ministre for Lord Bute in the old villa at the Abbey Hill, as I could have talked of the affairs of the Canning administration ; and even recalled, as a fresh picture  of his memory, his father drawing on his boots to go to make interest in London in behalf of some of the men in trouble for the forty-five, particularly his own brother-in- law, the Clanranald of that day.
